issue.title: (graphcache) - default storage's offline metadata not shared between 2 tabs
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Hi 👋,

This bug is from urql/offlineExchange.
When I'm in offline mode on both tabs:

**Tab 1 :**
I click several times on the "Click to simulate a new mutation" button (see demo link).
My queries fail because of the offline mode and are stored in metadata of indexedDB.
=> metadata (indexedDB) contains multiple queries.

**Tab 2 :**
I click once on the "Click to simulate a new mutation" button.
My request fails because of the offline mode and is stored in metadata of indexedDB.
=> metadata (indexedDB) now contains more than one query, others have been removed !

**Proposition of a solution :**
This bug occurs because we add an element in the failedQueue array without updating it just before with `storage.readMetadata()`
Here : https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/3dd23be7e41a2bd1db946f8626c6844fc5a1952c/exchanges/graphcache/src/offlineExchange.ts#L126-L130

The `flushQueue` function should use `storage.readMetadata()` instead to `failedQueue`
https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/3dd23be7e41a2bd1db946f8626c6844fc5a1952c/exchanges/graphcache/src/offlineExchange.ts#L102

### Reproduction

Source code : https://codesandbox.io/s/admiring-panini-yczq7c
Demo : https://yczq7c.csb.app/

### Urql version

"@urql/exchange-graphcache": "5.0.5"
"urql": "3.0.3"
  

### Validations

- [x] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/discussions) should be used
- [X] Read the [docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/).
- [X] Follow our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

comment.body:
I think, while it's possible for us to address this, I'm unsure of whether to actively track this, for two reasons basically,

The first reason is that we haven't address this exchange RFC yet: https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/issues/1062
While it's vaguely unrelated, I think, there's a chance that offline access will never be perfect between these two methods.

This blends into the second reason. While we're using IndexedDB, we strategically chose it becaus it's the only solution that's sufficiently fast for our cached data. Optimally for the metadata however, we'd want to instead use `localStorage` in an ideal world. However, it seemed like an odd choice to do both.

Consider this, if we allow two tabs do we also let both caches' override each others data? We probably would not want that either. Do we then try to additively add more data from both tabs? That can be really dangerous. Even though we split patches into periodic time segments, we have no guarantee that they'll merge cleanly between each other.

Hence, the only sane way to solve this is to have a synchronisation mechanism between tabs in place already that we could test at the same time — in fact, an optimal solution would synchronise the offline exchange's data backing between multiple tabs at all time anyway.

The reason why we haven't done this is the time/maintenance burden.
That's basically why we call it the "Default Storage" — to imply that it's not the only option. So I'll have to give this a quick think, but I reckon there may not be a complete solution here. If we fix the metadata issue, we may run straight ahead into a cache batch sync issue with the default storage.

issue.title: offline mode: asynchronous synchronization for request failure

labels.name: won't fix 🛑
labels.description: This issue won't be fixed as part of the current roadmap

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Hi 👋,

This bug is from urql/offlineExchange.

When I'm in offline mode :
I click several times on the "Click to simulate a new mutation" button. (see demo link)

When I'm in online mode :
the `flushQueue` function is call from [default-storage/index.ts](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/232310fa528095a6e0214804e313e785dda742f1/exchanges/graphcache/src/default-storage/index.ts#L206-L211).

But, all failed queries (stored in metadata of indexedDB) are retried at the same time. Because we don't wait for the previous request to be finished.

https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/3dd23be7e41a2bd1db946f8626c6844fc5a1952c/exchanges/graphcache/src/offlineExchange.ts#L109-L110

This problem causes a risk of data loss, for example when modifying an input several times in offline mode.
In online mode, during synchronization, the mutation that will be the last to modify the value is random.



### Reproduction

Sorry, I don't have a graphql server for this test, but you can watch the network in the browser.

Source code : https://codesandbox.io/s/admiring-panini-yczq7c
Demo : https://yczq7c.csb.app/

### Urql version

"@urql/exchange-graphcache": "5.0.5"
"urql": "3.0.3"

comment.body:
> are retried at the same time. Because we don't wait for the previous request to be finished.

I think, this is essentially what you're highlighting? Keep in mind that it's useful for you to describe what you're expecting rather than describing what's happening.

In this case, I'll have to close this issue — sorry! While we don't have an exchange yet that's officially mantained, we've made some mentions to the following technique.
When you have several mutations that are all running concurrently, and you instead want to queue them up, and run some sequentially, we recommend to implement a custom exchange. Otherwise, you have to basically accept the default behaviour.

There's no way for us to impose any restriction on this by default. If we ran all mutations in series, that wouldn't make much sense for most users. If we only did this in some circumstances; that's, in my opinion, also an unexpected implementation.

Rather, that's why we'd want to be explicit about this. When it's not safe to run a mutation concurrently with others, it's never safe — `offlineExchange` in Graphcache or otherwise.

I'll for now close this as "won't fix" in its current state. But not to worry if I got something wrong here, I'm happy to of course reopen and come back to it as needed

issue.title: RFC (Vue): Support usage in vue based web components with defineCustomElement

labels.name: future 🔮
labels.description: An enhancement or feature proposal that will be addressed after the next release

issue.body:
<!--
  🚨 RFCs are for proposed changes (not bugs or questions)
  Specifically they are whenever you'd like to see new features
  being added to urql, or enable new use-cases.
  They're also relevant whenever @urql/core is changed, since
  changes to e.g. the `Client` or `Exchange` types are kept rare
  and lean.
-->

## Summary
We have a micro app architecture relying on web components build with Vue's [defineCustomElements](https://vuejs.org/guide/extras/web-components.html#building-custom-elements-with-vue) function.
Therefor we have no app instance an no way to add urql as a plugin or use provide/inject.

A workaround would be of course not to use defineCustomelement and create the web components manually with an app instance, but we want to use defineCustomElement and reduce the manual work per web component (we will have probably 100+ web components in our mono repo).

## Proposed Solution

To enable this use case there are 2 possible changes that can achieve this:

**1. Add an optional client parameter to useClientHandle**
We could then use this parameter instead of useClient to get the client:
```ts
export function useClientHandle(clientArg?: Client): ClientHandle {
  const client = clientArg ?? useClient();
  //[...]
}
```

**2. Export all callUse\* functions**
If callUseQuery, callUseMutation, etc. functions are exported, we could build our own useClientHandle function based on those functions.

Solution 1 is the best solution if this should be an officially supported use case by `@urql/vue`. If not then solution 2 would allow a manual reuse of the vue functions for building a custom workaround. Both changes can also be implemented together of course.

If one (or both) of the proposed changes are welcome, I can provide a PR.

comment.body:
So, if I'm reading this correctly it does say,

> The Provide / Inject API and its Composition API equivalent also work between Vue-defined custom elements.

This is basically our mechanism to enforce that the Provide API is used to deliver a client to these APIs in a targeted manner. Bypassing this is of course possible — although, I will rule out option two here for you, sorry, it's simply not something we're keen on doing (a library, in our view, is not a set of tools to recompose said library, to us; this would diverge different usecases and happy paths too far between users)

Option 1 — providing a client ref or a client directly is of course possible. But, I want to make sure that this is necessary.

I haven't tested this myself yet, but could you validate for me please whether using `provideClient` in the same or a wrapping custom element that uses the query APIs really doesn't work? I think the docs imply it should 🤔 https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/9abce5d7b1f125d9edd666994e15ca8ae0dec7a6/packages/vue-urql/src/useClient.ts#L4

pull_request.body:
This PR was opened by the [Changesets release](https://github.com/changesets/action) GitHub action. When you're ready to do a release, you can merge this and the packages will be published to npm automatically. If you're not ready to do a release yet, that's fine, whenever you add more changesets to main, this PR will be updated.

# Releases
## @urql/exchange-graphcache@5.0.8

### Patch Changes

-   ⚠️ Fix operation being blocked for looping due to it not cancelling the looping protection when a `teardown` is received. This bug could be triggered when a shared query operation triggers again and causes a cache miss (e.g. due to an error). The re-execution of the operation would then be blocked as Graphcache considered it a "reexecution loop" rather than a legitimate execution triggered by the UI. (See <https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2737> for more information), by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2876](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2876))

issue.title: Urql doesn't make a http request to the server on component remount and gets stuck on fetching.
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

I'm making a request to graphql server for an object using it's id. But the id is incorrect and no such object exists. So, the resolver checks the id and database for the object and if it doesn't exists throws a GraphqlError. Urql client receives this error in the graphQLErrors list on error object returned from the query. I'm checking the error object and rendering error message to the screen.

The first time this page is rendered everything works fine and the error message is rendered. But if I navigate away from the page and come back to it since the component unmounts and remounts urql client again makes the fetch request to the server because error results are not cached by urql I presume. 

The problem is that the refetch happens but urql client never sends a request to the server. I'm saying this because the fetching state returned from urql client turns to true. So, basically it gets stuck. Please look into this issue.

The codesandbox link I've attached shows two pages. User with id = 1 renders the data response. User with id != 1 renders the error response. Navigate away from the page and go back to it again. You can see the fetching state is stuck on fetching = true. In the network tab there's no request made to the server.

### Reproduction

https://codesandbox.io/p/github/xoldyckk/urql_nextjs_error/draft/tender-keldysh

### Urql version

urql v3.0.3
next-urql v4.0.0

### Validations

- [X] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/discussions) should be used
- [X] Read the [docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/).
- [X] Follow our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

pull_request.title: fix(graphcache): Fix blocking of legitimate reexecutions after teardowns
pull_request.body:
Resolve #2835

## Summary

This fixes Graphcache blocking legitimate reexecutions triggerd by the UI. These reexecutions could be triggered due to the previously introduced looping protection #2737.

When an operation is torn down and reactivated without any other network request inbetween, then Graphcache wouldn't clean up the operations that'd be blocked from refetching. This meant that it'd erroneously block a legitimate operation triggered by the UI.

The protection is meant to only trigger requests that'd potentially infinitely trigger requests, i.e. non-`network-only` operations triggered by cache misses.

This has been addressed by adding a missing clean up call in reaction to teardowns.

## Set of changes

- Add missing `reexecutingOperations` clean up to `teardown` handler
- Remove typings/build testing line that we added to test a Rollup+TS build issue

comment.body:
I've taken a look and can confirm that this is an issue with the loop protection. We did recently fix another issue with it here, for reference: https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2831

The original implementation is here: https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2737

What we basically likely didn't account for are cases where the same query triggers again across multiple pages, i.e. explicit operations being triggered by the consuming client.

We'd likely have to find a way to better differentiate between `reexecuteOperation` loops and actual triggers in Graphcache, I'd suspect we'll need to take `teardown`s into account to check for this.

I'll see whether I can start a fix soon, and I'll link it to here once we do :v:

pull_request.title: fix(core): Fix regression causing stringifyDocument to not reprint after formatDocument
pull_request.body:
## Summary

Related to #2869 reproduces the issue.

[this](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/main/packages/core/src/utils/request.ts#L43-L53) looks to be the problem, when we use `createRequest` we fill in `gql` as the source name and don't update the printed string when looping over it with `formatDocument`. When we use `gql` the name will be `graphql request` hence not hitting this clause.

The thing concerning me here is if people would be implementing local-only exchanges whether that would mess with i.e. them removing a field when seeing `@local`

pull_request.title: Version Packages
pull_request.body:
This PR was opened by the [Changesets release](https://github.com/changesets/action) GitHub action. When you're ready to do a release, you can merge this and the packages will be published to npm automatically. If you're not ready to do a release yet, that's fine, whenever you add more changesets to main, this PR will be updated.

# Releases
## @urql/exchange-execute@2.1.0

### Minor Changes

-   The `context` option, which may be set to a context value or a function returning a context, can now return a `Promise` and will be correctly resolved and awaited, by [@YutaUra](https://github.com/YutaUra) (See [#2806](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2806))

### Patch Changes

-   End iterator when teardown functions runs, previously it waited for one extra call to next, then ended the iterator, by [@danielkaxis](https://github.com/danielkaxis) (See [#2803](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2803))
-   Updated dependencies (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843), [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847), [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850), and [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))
    -   @urql/core@3.1.0

 ## @urql/core@3.1.0

### Minor Changes

-   Implement `mapExchange`, which replaces `errorExchange`, allowing `onOperation` and `onResult` to be called to either react to or replace operations and results. For backwards compatibility, this exchange is also exported as `errorExchange` and supports `onError`, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))

### Patch Changes

-   Move remaining `Variables` generics over from `object` default to `Variables extends AnyVariables = AnyVariables`. This has been introduced previously in [#2607](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2607) but some missing ports have been missed due to TypeScript not catching them previously. Depending on your TypeScript version the `object` default is incompatible with `AnyVariables`, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843))
-   Reuse output of `stringifyDocument` in place of repeated `print`. This will mean that we now prevent calling `print` repeatedly for identical operations and are instead only reusing the result once.
    This change has a subtle consequence of our internals. Operation keys will change due to this
    refactor and we will no longer sanitise strip newlines from queries that `@urql/core` has printed, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847))
-   Update to `wonka@^6.1.2` to fix memory leak in `fetch` caused in Node.js by a lack of clean up after initiating a request, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850))

 ## @urql/exchange-graphcache@5.0.6

### Patch Changes

-   Solve issue where partial data could cause loops between related queries, by [@JoviDeCroock](https://github.com/JoviDeCroock) (See [#2831](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2831))
-   Add skipping of garbage collection runs when the cache is waiting for optimistic, deferred or other results in layers. This means that we only take an opportunity to run garbage collection after results have settled and are hence decreasing the chance of hogging the event loop when a run isn't needed, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2862](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2862))
-   ⚠️ Fix a deadlock condition in Graphcache's layers, which is caused by subscriptions (or other deferred layers) starting before one-off mutation layers. This causes the mutation to not be completed, which keeps its data preferred above the deferred layer. That in turn means that layers stop squashing, which causes new results to be missing indefinitely, when they overlap, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2861](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2861))
-   Updated dependencies (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843), [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847), [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850), and [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))
    -   @urql/core@3.1.0

 ## next-urql@4.0.1

### Patch Changes

-   Change import for `createClient` to `@urql/core`, which helps Next not depend on `urql` and hence not cause `createContext` to be called when the import is treeshaken away, by [@SleeplessOne1917](https://github.com/SleeplessOne1917) (See [#2833](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2833))

 ## @urql/svelte@3.0.2

### Patch Changes

-   Move remaining `Variables` generics over from `object` default to `Variables extends AnyVariables = AnyVariables`. This has been introduced previously in [#2607](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2607) but some missing ports have been missed due to TypeScript not catching them previously. Depending on your TypeScript version the `object` default is incompatible with `AnyVariables`, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843))
-   Updated dependencies (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843), [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847), [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850), and [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))
    -   @urql/core@3.1.0

 ## @urql/vue@1.0.3

### Patch Changes

-   Move remaining `Variables` generics over from `object` default to `Variables extends AnyVariables = AnyVariables`. This has been introduced previously in [#2607](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2607) but some missing ports have been missed due to TypeScript not catching them previously. Depending on your TypeScript version the `object` default is incompatible with `AnyVariables`, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843))
-   Updated dependencies (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843), [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847), [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850), and [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))
    -   @urql/core@3.1.0

commits.message: feat(graphcache): Remove refLock and add dirtyKeys / skip GC runs in unsettled states (#2862)

pull_request.title: feat(graphcache): Remove refLock and add dirtyKeys / skip GC runs in unsettled states
pull_request.body:
## Summary

This skips GC runs when we previously would've used `refLock` to skip over entities that are "locked" by optimistic and deferred layers. Instead, we now simply skip GC runs when `optimisticOrder` is non-empty, meaning that we simply forgo garbage collection runs when we know it's unlikely we'll need them.

The motivation of this change is to reduce the complexity of `InMemoryData` code further, and to remove the added work and event loop pressure by scheduling garbage collection runs when we could simply wait a bit longer to schedule it.

## Set of changes

- Remove `refLock` from data
- Add `dirtyKeys` instead, to track layers we've created
- Update tests to ignore skipped optimistic runs
- Simplify the GC, RC, and `writeLink` code

issue.title: RFC: Memoize the printing of queries

labels.name: future 🔮
labels.description: An enhancement or feature proposal that will be addressed after the next release

issue.body:
## Summary

✌️ @jian-ong

We note that the `formatDocument` util uses memoization to avoid walking over the same query AST multiple times:

https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/30ecefe9f69a4c33849f6c9c43bf5083b35878c2/packages/core/src/utils/typenames.ts#L64

In our application we have observed a similar bottleneck with the `print` function from the `graphql` module. Many pages use the same query with different variables, but they are all having to print the exact same query.

## Proposed Solution

We propose adding a `Map` to the `makeFetchBody` function to memoize printing of GraphQL queries in a similar way to the `formatDocument` util.

Example implementation:
https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/commit/7edb1e2072d124fb331953ec38156f2a4f564270

We are keen to hear your feedback on this. Are there other use-cases where this would be a problem, for example queries being constructed dynamically at runtime, resulting in different query keys, or is that not a supported use-case?

commits.message: feat(core): Reuse stringifyDocument and cached prints across @urql/core (#2847)

pull_request.title: feat(core): Reuse stringifyDocument and cached prints across @urql/core
pull_request.body:
Resolves #2787

## Summary

This changes the internals of `@urql/core` to allow us to reuse `stringifyDocument` in `fetchOptions` and other places, to ensure that printing is memoised whenever possible — including for `formatDocument` outputs.

This means that we had to adjust our hashing slightly to account for the different outputs; that said, sanitisation will still be applied to `stringifyDocument` inputs. However, we will no longer reuse `loc.source` strings when they haven't been printed by `@urql/core`.

## Set of changes

- Replace `phash` hashing function and create opaque type for clarity
- Refactor `request.ts`' `stringifyDocument` and hashing
- Reuse `stringifyDocument` in `subscriptionExchange` and `fetchOptions`
- Update document sanitisation to only remove comments
- Update hashing to add the operation name only to the hash key, rather than the `stringifyDocument` output

issue.title: Subscription doesn't update records after mutation
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Hello!

I believe I found a bug in urql subscriptions. I prepared a simple list, where users can add new records and rename existing ones. After a user creates a new record and after that they hit "Rename" button, updated results won't show up. The "Rename" button calls standalone gql client (not urql) just to simulate external source of change -- this way I'm sure urql doesn't know about mutation been called and so urql must update cache from subscription.

I also attached video: 

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1828134/205616233-c8c9d41e-e772-438f-a23f-c262d41e247e.mov

Or am I doing something wrong?

### Reproduction

https://github.com/cinan/urql-cache

### Urql version

@urql/exchange-graphcache: 5.0.5
urql: 3.0.3


### Validations

- [X] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/discussions) should be used
- [X] Read the [docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/).
- [X] Follow our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

pull_request.title: fix(graphcache): Fix deadlocked layers between deferred and optimistic layers
pull_request.body:
Resolve #2853

## Summary

This fixes a deadlock that could occur in the layers of Graphcache, when a deferred layer (subscriptions or otherwise `hasNext` layers) would be moved past previously optimistic layers (like mutations). In such cases, it would become impossible for preceding layers (i.e. mutations) to ever squash and move "out of the way" causing a deadlock that'd make it impossible for the deferred layer's data to show up when the two layers had overlaps.

Instead, we now will try to clear out deferred layers more aggressively. This means that we will squash its data even when it's deferred, when data is written.

Furthermore, we then move the layer from its current position (or recreate it) when it's re-registered, i.e. when a new message/update comes in for the deferred layer.

This should keep the deferred layers data in the cache but still bump it as needed.

## Set of changes

- Allow deferred layers to be squashed
- Allow layers to only move past empty ones from its current position in the `optimisticOrder` list

comment.body:
Here, as discussed, we realised that deferred layers should 100% be squasheable. We basially put deferred layers in the right place, write to them, and then ... we assume that they're never squasheable.

This means that for subscriptions (or other neverending result streams) this layer never goes away, and pending layers that then were on top can never go away either, and have the potential to infinitely be "in the way" of old deferred layers.

pull_request.title: fix(graphcache): Fix deadlocked layers between deferred and optimistic layers
pull_request.body:
**This is a work in progress**

Resolve #2853

## Summary

This fixes a deadlock that could occur in the layers of Graphcache, when a deferred layer (subscriptions or otherwise `hasNext` layers) would be moved past previously optimistic layers (like mutations). In such cases, it would become impossible for preceding layers (i.e. mutations) to ever squash and move "out of the way" causing a deadlock that'd make it impossible for the deferred layer's data to show up when the two layers had overlaps.

Instead, we now will try to clear out deferred layers more aggressively. This means that we will squash its data even when it's deferred, when data is written.

Furthermore, we then move the layer from its current position (or recreate it) when it's re-registered, i.e. when a new message/update comes in for the deferred layer.

This should keep the deferred layers data in the cache but still bump it as needed.

## Set of changes

- Allow deferred layers to be squashed
- Allow layers to only move past empty ones from its current position in the `optimisticOrder` list

comment.body:
Please check the types and docs :v:

Prepass does not return React elements and hence your `const node` variable is being set to `undefined`: https://github.com/FormidableLabs/react-ssr-prepass/blob/099119761074dc35d2bc0d884297e6c84c77f684/src/index.js#L61

issue.title: (graphcache) - default storage's offline metadata not shared between 2 tabs
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Hi 👋,

This bug is from urql/offlineExchange.
When I'm in offline mode on both tabs:

**Tab 1 :**
I click several times on the "Click to simulate a new mutation" button (see demo link).
My queries fail because of the offline mode and are stored in metadata of indexedDB.
=> metadata (indexedDB) contains multiple queries.

**Tab 2 :**
I click once on the "Click to simulate a new mutation" button.
My request fails because of the offline mode and is stored in metadata of indexedDB.
=> metadata (indexedDB) now contains more than one query, others have been removed !

**Proposition of a solution :**
This bug occurs because we add an element in the failedQueue array without updating it just before with `storage.readMetadata()`
Here : https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/3dd23be7e41a2bd1db946f8626c6844fc5a1952c/exchanges/graphcache/src/offlineExchange.ts#L126-L130

The `flushQueue` function should use `storage.readMetadata()` instead to `failedQueue`
https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/3dd23be7e41a2bd1db946f8626c6844fc5a1952c/exchanges/graphcache/src/offlineExchange.ts#L102

### Reproduction

Source code : https://codesandbox.io/s/admiring-panini-yczq7c
Demo : https://yczq7c.csb.app/

### Urql version

"@urql/exchange-graphcache": "5.0.5"
"urql": "3.0.3"
  

### Validations

- [x] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/discussions) should be used
- [X] Read the [docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/).
- [X] Follow our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

comment.body:
I think, while it's possible for us to address this, I'm unsure of whether to actively track this, for two reasons basically,

The first reason is that we haven't address this exchange RFC yet: https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/issues/1062
While it's vaguely unrelated, I think, there's a chance that offline access will never be perfect between these two methods.

This blends into the second reason. While we're using IndexedDB, we strategically chose it becaus it's the only solution that's sufficiently fast for our cached data. Optimally for the metadata however, we'd want to instead use `localStorage` in an ideal world. However, it seemed like an odd choice to do both.

Consider this, if we allow two tabs do we also let both caches' override each others data? We probably would not want that either. Do we then try to additively add more data from both tabs? That can be really dangerous. Even though we split patches into periodic time segments, we have no guarantee that they'll merge cleanly between each other.

Hence, the only sane way to solve this is to have a synchronisation mechanism between tabs in place already that we could test at the same time — in fact, an optimal solution would synchronise the offline exchange's data backing between multiple tabs at all time anyway.

The reason why we haven't done this is the time/maintenance burden.
That's basically why we call it the "Default Storage" — to imply that it's not the only option. So I'll have to give this a quick think, but I reckon there may not be a complete solution here. If we fix the metadata issue, we may run straight ahead into a cache batch sync issue with the default storage.

issue.title: offline mode: asynchronous synchronization for request failure

labels.name: won't fix 🛑
labels.description: This issue won't be fixed as part of the current roadmap

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Hi 👋,

This bug is from urql/offlineExchange.

When I'm in offline mode :
I click several times on the "Click to simulate a new mutation" button. (see demo link)

When I'm in online mode :
the `flushQueue` function is call from [default-storage/index.ts](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/232310fa528095a6e0214804e313e785dda742f1/exchanges/graphcache/src/default-storage/index.ts#L206-L211).

But, all failed queries (stored in metadata of indexedDB) are retried at the same time. Because we don't wait for the previous request to be finished.

https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/3dd23be7e41a2bd1db946f8626c6844fc5a1952c/exchanges/graphcache/src/offlineExchange.ts#L109-L110

This problem causes a risk of data loss, for example when modifying an input several times in offline mode.
In online mode, during synchronization, the mutation that will be the last to modify the value is random.



### Reproduction

Sorry, I don't have a graphql server for this test, but you can watch the network in the browser.

Source code : https://codesandbox.io/s/admiring-panini-yczq7c
Demo : https://yczq7c.csb.app/

### Urql version

"@urql/exchange-graphcache": "5.0.5"
"urql": "3.0.3"

### Validations

- [X] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/discussions) should be used

comment.body:
> are retried at the same time. Because we don't wait for the previous request to be finished.

I think, this is essentially what you're highlighting? Keep in mind that it's useful for you to describe what you're expecting rather than describing what's happening.

In this case, I'll have to close this issue — sorry! While we don't have an exchange yet that's officially mantained, we've made some mentions to the following technique.
When you have several mutations that are all running concurrently, and you instead want to queue them up, and run some sequentially, we recommend to implement a custom exchange. Otherwise, you have to basically accept the default behaviour.

There's no way for us to impose any restriction on this by default. If we ran all mutations in series, that wouldn't make much sense for most users. If we only did this in some circumstances; that's, in my opinion, also an unexpected implementation.

Rather, that's why we'd want to be explicit about this. When it's not safe to run a mutation concurrently with others, it's never safe — `offlineExchange` in Graphcache or otherwise.

I'll for now close this as "won't fix" in its current state. But not to worry if I got something wrong here, I'm happy to of course reopen and come back to it as needed

issue.title: RFC (Vue): Support usage in vue based web components with defineCustomElement

labels.name: future 🔮
labels.description: An enhancement or feature proposal that will be addressed after the next release

issue.body:
<!--
  🚨 RFCs are for proposed changes (not bugs or questions)
  Specifically they are whenever you'd like to see new features
  being added to urql, or enable new use-cases.
  They're also relevant whenever @urql/core is changed, since
  changes to e.g. the `Client` or `Exchange` types are kept rare
  and lean.
-->

## Summary
We have a micro app architecture relying on web components build with Vue's [defineCustomElements](https://vuejs.org/guide/extras/web-components.html#building-custom-elements-with-vue) function.
Therefor we have no app instance an no way to add urql as a plugin or use provide/inject.

A workaround would be of course not to use defineCustomelement and create the web components manually with an app instance, but we want to use defineCustomElement and reduce the manual work per web component (we will have probably 100+ web components in our mono repo).

## Proposed Solution

To enable this use case there are 2 possible changes that can achieve this:

**1. Add an optional client parameter to useClientHandle**
We could then use this parameter instead of useClient to get the client:
```ts
export function useClientHandle(clientArg?: Client): ClientHandle {
  const client = clientArg ?? useClient();
  //[...]
}
```

**2. Export all callUse\* functions**
If callUseQuery, callUseMutation, etc. functions are exported, we could build our own useClientHandle function based on those functions.

Solution 1 is the best solution if this should be an officially supported use case by `@urql/vue`. If not then solution 2 would allow a manual reuse of the vue functions for building a custom workaround. Both changes can also be implemented together of course.

If one (or both) of the proposed changes are welcome, I can provide a PR.

comment.body:
So, if I'm reading this correctly it does say,

> The Provide / Inject API and its Composition API equivalent also work between Vue-defined custom elements.

This is basically our mechanism to enforce that the Provide API is used to deliver a client to these APIs in a targeted manner. Bypassing this is of course possible — although, I will rule out option two here for you, sorry, it's simply not something we're keen on doing (a library, in our view, is not a set of tools to recompose said library, to us; this would diverge different usecases and happy paths too far between users)

Option 1 — providing a client ref or a client directly is of course possible. But, I want to make sure that this is necessary.

I haven't tested this myself yet, but could you validate for me please whether using `provideClient` in the same or a wrapping custom element that uses the query APIs really doesn't work? I think the docs imply it should 🤔 https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/9abce5d7b1f125d9edd666994e15ca8ae0dec7a6/packages/vue-urql/src/useClient.ts#L4

Version Packages (#2880)

pull_request.title: Version Packages
pull_request.body:
This PR was opened by the [Changesets release](https://github.com/changesets/action) GitHub action. When you're ready to do a release, you can merge this and the packages will be published to npm automatically. If you're not ready to do a release yet, that's fine, whenever you add more changesets to main, this PR will be updated.

# Releases
## @urql/exchange-graphcache@5.0.8

### Patch Changes

-   ⚠️ Fix operation being blocked for looping due to it not cancelling the looping protection when a `teardown` is received. This bug could be triggered when a shared query operation triggers again and causes a cache miss (e.g. due to an error). The re-execution of the operation would then be blocked as Graphcache considered it a "reexecution loop" rather than a legitimate execution triggered by the UI. (See <https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2737> for more information), by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2876](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2876))

issue.title: Urql doesn't make a http request to the server on component remount and gets stuck on fetching.
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

I'm making a request to graphql server for an object using it's id. But the id is incorrect and no such object exists. So, the resolver checks the id and database for the object and if it doesn't exists throws a GraphqlError. Urql client receives this error in the graphQLErrors list on error object returned from the query. I'm checking the error object and rendering error message to the screen.

The first time this page is rendered everything works fine and the error message is rendered. But if I navigate away from the page and come back to it since the component unmounts and remounts urql client again makes the fetch request to the server because error results are not cached by urql I presume. 

The problem is that the refetch happens but urql client never sends a request to the server. I'm saying this because the fetching state returned from urql client turns to true. So, basically it gets stuck. Please look into this issue.

The codesandbox link I've attached shows two pages. User with id = 1 renders the data response. User with id != 1 renders the error response. Navigate away from the page and go back to it again. You can see the fetching state is stuck on fetching = true. In the network tab there's no request made to the server.

### Reproduction

https://codesandbox.io/p/github/xoldyckk/urql_nextjs_error/draft/tender-keldysh

### Urql version

urql v3.0.3
next-urql v4.0.0

### Validations

- [X] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/discussions) should be used
- [X] Read the [docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/).
- [X] Follow our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

pull_request.title: fix(graphcache): Fix blocking of legitimate reexecutions after teardowns
pull_request.body:
Resolve #2835

## Summary

This fixes Graphcache blocking legitimate reexecutions triggerd by the UI. These reexecutions could be triggered due to the previously introduced looping protection #2737.

When an operation is torn down and reactivated without any other network request inbetween, then Graphcache wouldn't clean up the operations that'd be blocked from refetching. This meant that it'd erroneously block a legitimate operation triggered by the UI.

The protection is meant to only trigger requests that'd potentially infinitely trigger requests, i.e. non-`network-only` operations triggered by cache misses.

This has been addressed by adding a missing clean up call in reaction to teardowns.

## Set of changes

- Add missing `reexecutingOperations` clean up to `teardown` handler
- Remove typings/build testing line that we added to test a Rollup+TS build issue

comment.body:
I've taken a look and can confirm that this is an issue with the loop protection. We did recently fix another issue with it here, for reference: https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2831

The original implementation is here: https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2737

What we basically likely didn't account for are cases where the same query triggers again across multiple pages, i.e. explicit operations being triggered by the consuming client.

We'd likely have to find a way to better differentiate between `reexecuteOperation` loops and actual triggers in Graphcache, I'd suspect we'll need to take `teardown`s into account to check for this.

I'll see whether I can start a fix soon, and I'll link it to here once we do :v:

pull_request.title: fix(core): Fix regression causing stringifyDocument to not reprint after formatDocument
pull_request.body:
## Summary

Related to #2869 reproduces the issue.

[this](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/main/packages/core/src/utils/request.ts#L43-L53) looks to be the problem, when we use `createRequest` we fill in `gql` as the source name and don't update the printed string when looping over it with `formatDocument`. When we use `gql` the name will be `graphql request` hence not hitting this clause.

The thing concerning me here is if people would be implementing local-only exchanges whether that would mess with i.e. them removing a field when seeing `@local`

pull_request.title: Version Packages
pull_request.body:
This PR was opened by the [Changesets release](https://github.com/changesets/action) GitHub action. When you're ready to do a release, you can merge this and the packages will be published to npm automatically. If you're not ready to do a release yet, that's fine, whenever you add more changesets to main, this PR will be updated.

# Releases
## @urql/exchange-execute@2.1.0

### Minor Changes

-   The `context` option, which may be set to a context value or a function returning a context, can now return a `Promise` and will be correctly resolved and awaited, by [@YutaUra](https://github.com/YutaUra) (See [#2806](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2806))

### Patch Changes

-   End iterator when teardown functions runs, previously it waited for one extra call to next, then ended the iterator, by [@danielkaxis](https://github.com/danielkaxis) (See [#2803](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2803))
-   Updated dependencies (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843), [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847), [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850), and [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))
    -   @urql/core@3.1.0

 ## @urql/core@3.1.0

### Minor Changes

-   Implement `mapExchange`, which replaces `errorExchange`, allowing `onOperation` and `onResult` to be called to either react to or replace operations and results. For backwards compatibility, this exchange is also exported as `errorExchange` and supports `onError`, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))

### Patch Changes

-   Move remaining `Variables` generics over from `object` default to `Variables extends AnyVariables = AnyVariables`. This has been introduced previously in [#2607](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2607) but some missing ports have been missed due to TypeScript not catching them previously. Depending on your TypeScript version the `object` default is incompatible with `AnyVariables`, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843))
-   Reuse output of `stringifyDocument` in place of repeated `print`. This will mean that we now prevent calling `print` repeatedly for identical operations and are instead only reusing the result once.
    This change has a subtle consequence of our internals. Operation keys will change due to this
    refactor and we will no longer sanitise strip newlines from queries that `@urql/core` has printed, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847))
-   Update to `wonka@^6.1.2` to fix memory leak in `fetch` caused in Node.js by a lack of clean up after initiating a request, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850))

 ## @urql/exchange-graphcache@5.0.6

### Patch Changes

-   Solve issue where partial data could cause loops between related queries, by [@JoviDeCroock](https://github.com/JoviDeCroock) (See [#2831](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2831))
-   Add skipping of garbage collection runs when the cache is waiting for optimistic, deferred or other results in layers. This means that we only take an opportunity to run garbage collection after results have settled and are hence decreasing the chance of hogging the event loop when a run isn't needed, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2862](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2862))
-   ⚠️ Fix a deadlock condition in Graphcache's layers, which is caused by subscriptions (or other deferred layers) starting before one-off mutation layers. This causes the mutation to not be completed, which keeps its data preferred above the deferred layer. That in turn means that layers stop squashing, which causes new results to be missing indefinitely, when they overlap, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2861](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2861))
-   Updated dependencies (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843), [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847), [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850), and [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))
    -   @urql/core@3.1.0

 ## next-urql@4.0.1

### Patch Changes

-   Change import for `createClient` to `@urql/core`, which helps Next not depend on `urql` and hence not cause `createContext` to be called when the import is treeshaken away, by [@SleeplessOne1917](https://github.com/SleeplessOne1917) (See [#2833](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2833))

 ## @urql/svelte@3.0.2

### Patch Changes

-   Move remaining `Variables` generics over from `object` default to `Variables extends AnyVariables = AnyVariables`. This has been introduced previously in [#2607](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2607) but some missing ports have been missed due to TypeScript not catching them previously. Depending on your TypeScript version the `object` default is incompatible with `AnyVariables`, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843))
-   Updated dependencies (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843), [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847), [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850), and [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))
    -   @urql/core@3.1.0

 ## @urql/vue@1.0.3

### Patch Changes

-   Move remaining `Variables` generics over from `object` default to `Variables extends AnyVariables = AnyVariables`. This has been introduced previously in [#2607](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2607) but some missing ports have been missed due to TypeScript not catching them previously. Depending on your TypeScript version the `object` default is incompatible with `AnyVariables`, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843))
-   Updated dependencies (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843), [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847), [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850), and [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))
    -   @urql/core@3.1.0

This means that we only take an opportunity to run garbage collection after results have settled and are hence decreasing the chance of hogging the event loop when a run isn't needed, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2862](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2862))
-   ⚠️ Fix a deadlock condition in Graphcache's layers, which is caused by subscriptions (or other deferred layers) starting before one-off mutation layers. This causes the mutation to not be completed, which keeps its data preferred above the deferred layer. That in turn means that layers stop squashing, which causes new results to be missing indefinitely, when they overlap, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2861](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2861))
-   Updated dependencies (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843), [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847), [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850), and [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))
    -   @urql/core@3.1.0

 ## next-urql@4.0.1

### Patch Changes

-   Change import for `createClient` to `@urql/core`, which helps Next not depend on `urql` and hence not cause `createContext` to be called when the import is treeshaken away, by [@SleeplessOne1917](https://github.com/SleeplessOne1917) (See [#2833](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2833))

 ## @urql/svelte@3.0.2

### Patch Changes

-   Move remaining `Variables` generics over from `object` default to `Variables extends AnyVariables = AnyVariables`. This has been introduced previously in [#2607](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2607) but some missing ports have been missed due to TypeScript not catching them previously. Depending on your TypeScript version the `object` default is incompatible with `AnyVariables`, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843))
-   Updated dependencies (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843), [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847), [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850), and [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))
    -   @urql/core@3.1.0

 ## @urql/vue@1.0.3

### Patch Changes

-   Move remaining `Variables` generics over from `object` default to `Variables extends AnyVariables = AnyVariables`. This has been introduced previously in [#2607](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2607) but some missing ports have been missed due to TypeScript not catching them previously. Depending on your TypeScript version the `object` default is incompatible with `AnyVariables`, by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843))
-   Updated dependencies (See [#2843](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2843), [#2847](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2847), [#2850](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2850), and [#2846](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2846))

commits.message: feat(graphcache): Remove refLock and add dirtyKeys / skip GC runs in unsettled states (#2862)

pull_request.title: feat(graphcache): Remove refLock and add dirtyKeys / skip GC runs in unsettled states
pull_request.body:
## Summary

This skips GC runs when we previously would've used `refLock` to skip over entities that are "locked" by optimistic and deferred layers. Instead, we now simply skip GC runs when `optimisticOrder` is non-empty, meaning that we simply forgo garbage collection runs when we know it's unlikely we'll need them.

The motivation of this change is to reduce the complexity of `InMemoryData` code further, and to remove the added work and event loop pressure by scheduling garbage collection runs when we could simply wait a bit longer to schedule it.

## Set of changes

- Remove `refLock` from data
- Add `dirtyKeys` instead, to track layers we've created
- Update tests to ignore skipped optimistic runs
- Simplify the GC, RC, and `writeLink` code

issue.title: RFC: Memoize the printing of queries

labels.name: future 🔮
labels.description: An enhancement or feature proposal that will be addressed after the next release

issue.body:
## Summary

✌️ @jian-ong

We note that the `formatDocument` util uses memoization to avoid walking over the same query AST multiple times:

https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/blob/30ecefe9f69a4c33849f6c9c43bf5083b35878c2/packages/core/src/utils/typenames.ts#L64

In our application we have observed a similar bottleneck with the `print` function from the `graphql` module. Many pages use the same query with different variables, but they are all having to print the exact same query.

## Proposed Solution

We propose adding a `Map` to the `makeFetchBody` function to memoize printing of GraphQL queries in a similar way to the `formatDocument` util.

Example implementation:
https://github.com/FormidableLabs/urql/commit/7edb1e2072d124fb331953ec38156f2a4f564270

We are keen to hear your feedback on this. Are there other use-cases where this would be a problem, for example queries being constructed dynamically at runtime, resulting in different query keys, or is that not a supported use-case?

pull_request.title: feat(core): Reuse stringifyDocument and cached prints across @urql/core
pull_request.body:
Resolves #2787

## Summary

This changes the internals of `@urql/core` to allow us to reuse `stringifyDocument` in `fetchOptions` and other places, to ensure that printing is memoised whenever possible — including for `formatDocument` outputs.

This means that we had to adjust our hashing slightly to account for the different outputs; that said, sanitisation will still be applied to `stringifyDocument` inputs. However, we will no longer reuse `loc.source` strings when they haven't been printed by `@urql/core`.

## Set of changes

- Replace `phash` hashing function and create opaque type for clarity
- Refactor `request.ts`' `stringifyDocument` and hashing
- Reuse `stringifyDocument` in `subscriptionExchange` and `fetchOptions`
- Update document sanitisation to only remove comments
- Update hashing to add the operation name only to the hash key, rather than the `stringifyDocument` output

issue.title: Subscription doesn't update records after mutation
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Hello!

I believe I found a bug in urql subscriptions. I prepared a simple list, where users can add new records and rename existing ones. After a user creates a new record and after that they hit "Rename" button, updated results won't show up. The "Rename" button calls standalone gql client (not urql) just to simulate external source of change -- this way I'm sure urql doesn't know about mutation been called and so urql must update cache from subscription.

I also attached video: 

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1828134/205616233-c8c9d41e-e772-438f-a23f-c262d41e247e.mov

Or am I doing something wrong?

### Reproduction

https://github.com/cinan/urql-cache

### Urql version

@urql/exchange-graphcache: 5.0.5
urql: 3.0.3


### Validations

- [X] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/discussions) should be used
- [X] Read the [docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/).
- [X] Follow our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

pull_request.title: fix(graphcache): Fix deadlocked layers between deferred and optimistic layers
pull_request.body:
Resolve #2853

## Summary

This fixes a deadlock that could occur in the layers of Graphcache, when a deferred layer (subscriptions or otherwise `hasNext` layers) would be moved past previously optimistic layers (like mutations). In such cases, it would become impossible for preceding layers (i.e. mutations) to ever squash and move "out of the way" causing a deadlock that'd make it impossible for the deferred layer's data to show up when the two layers had overlaps.

Instead, we now will try to clear out deferred layers more aggressively. This means that we will squash its data even when it's deferred, when data is written.

Furthermore, we then move the layer from its current position (or recreate it) when it's re-registered, i.e. when a new message/update comes in for the deferred layer.

This should keep the deferred layers data in the cache but still bump it as needed.

## Set of changes

- Allow deferred layers to be squashed
- Allow layers to only move past empty ones from its current position in the `optimisticOrder` list

comment.body:
Here, as discussed, we realised that deferred layers should 100% be squasheable. We basially put deferred layers in the right place, write to them, and then ... we assume that they're never squasheable.

This means that for subscriptions (or other neverending result streams) this layer never goes away, and pending layers that then were on top can never go away either, and have the potential to infinitely be "in the way" of old deferred layers.

Prepass does not return React elements and hence your `const node` variable is being set to `undefined`: https://github.com/FormidableLabs/react-ssr-prepass/blob/099119761074dc35d2bc0d884297e6c84c77f684/src/index.js#L61

issue.title: (graphcache) - default storage's offline metadata not shared between 2 tabs
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Hi 👋,

This bug is from urql/offlineExchange.
When I'm in offline mode on both tabs:

**Tab 1 :**
I click several times on the "Click to simulate a new mutation" button (see demo link).
My queries fail because of the offline mode and are stored in metadata of indexedDB.
=> metadata (indexedDB) contains multiple queries.

**Tab 2 :**
I click once on the "Click to simulate a new mutation" button.
My request fails because of the offline mode and is stored in metadata of indexedDB.
=> metadata (indexedDB) now contains more than one query, others have been removed !

**Proposition of a solution :**
This bug occurs because we add an element in the failedQueue array without updating it just before with `storage.readMetadata()`
Here : https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/3dd23be7e41a2bd1db946f8626c6844fc5a1952c/exchanges/graphcache/src/offlineExchange.ts#L126-L130

The `flushQueue` function should use `storage.readMetadata()` instead to `failedQueue`
https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/3dd23be7e41a2bd1db946f8626c6844fc5a1952c/exchanges/graphcache/src/offlineExchange.ts#L102

### Reproduction

Source code : https://codesandbox.io/s/admiring-panini-yczq7c
Demo : https://yczq7c.csb.app/

### Urql version

"@urql/exchange-graphcache": "5.0.5"
"urql": "3.0.3"
  

### Validations

- [x] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/discussions) should be used
- [X] Read the [docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/).
- [X] Follow our [Code of Conduct](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/main/CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md)

comment.body:
I think, while it's possible for us to address this, I'm unsure of whether to actively track this, for two reasons basically,

The first reason is that we haven't address this exchange RFC yet: https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/issues/1062
While it's vaguely unrelated, I think, there's a chance that offline access will never be perfect between these two methods.

This blends into the second reason. While we're using IndexedDB, we strategically chose it becaus it's the only solution that's sufficiently fast for our cached data. Optimally for the metadata however, we'd want to instead use `localStorage` in an ideal world. However, it seemed like an odd choice to do both.

Consider this, if we allow two tabs do we also let both caches' override each others data? We probably would not want that either. Do we then try to additively add more data from both tabs? That can be really dangerous. Even though we split patches into periodic time segments, we have no guarantee that they'll merge cleanly between each other.

Hence, the only sane way to solve this is to have a synchronisation mechanism between tabs in place already that we could test at the same time — in fact, an optimal solution would synchronise the offline exchange's data backing between multiple tabs at all time anyway.

The reason why we haven't done this is the time/maintenance burden.
That's basically why we call it the "Default Storage" — to imply that it's not the only option. So I'll have to give this a quick think, but I reckon there may not be a complete solution here. If we fix the metadata issue, we may run straight ahead into a cache batch sync issue with the default storage.

issue.title: offline mode: asynchronous synchronization for request failure

labels.name: won't fix 🛑
labels.description: This issue won't be fixed as part of the current roadmap

issue.body:
### Describe the bug

Hi 👋,

This bug is from urql/offlineExchange.

When I'm in offline mode :
I click several times on the "Click to simulate a new mutation" button. (see demo link)

When I'm in online mode :
the `flushQueue` function is call from [default-storage/index.ts](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/232310fa528095a6e0214804e313e785dda742f1/exchanges/graphcache/src/default-storage/index.ts#L206-L211).

But, all failed queries (stored in metadata of indexedDB) are retried at the same time. Because we don't wait for the previous request to be finished.

https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/3dd23be7e41a2bd1db946f8626c6844fc5a1952c/exchanges/graphcache/src/offlineExchange.ts#L109-L110

This problem causes a risk of data loss, for example when modifying an input several times in offline mode.
In online mode, during synchronization, the mutation that will be the last to modify the value is random.



### Reproduction

Sorry, I don't have a graphql server for this test, but you can watch the network in the browser.

Source code : https://codesandbox.io/s/admiring-panini-yczq7c
Demo : https://yczq7c.csb.app/

### Urql version

"@urql/exchange-graphcache": "5.0.5"
"urql": "3.0.3"

comment.body:
> are retried at the same time. Because we don't wait for the previous request to be finished.

I think, this is essentially what you're highlighting? Keep in mind that it's useful for you to describe what you're expecting rather than describing what's happening.

In this case, I'll have to close this issue — sorry! While we don't have an exchange yet that's officially mantained, we've made some mentions to the following technique.
When you have several mutations that are all running concurrently, and you instead want to queue them up, and run some sequentially, we recommend to implement a custom exchange. Otherwise, you have to basically accept the default behaviour.

There's no way for us to impose any restriction on this by default. If we ran all mutations in series, that wouldn't make much sense for most users. If we only did this in some circumstances; that's, in my opinion, also an unexpected implementation.

Rather, that's why we'd want to be explicit about this. When it's not safe to run a mutation concurrently with others, it's never safe — `offlineExchange` in Graphcache or otherwise.

I'll for now close this as "won't fix" in its current state. But not to worry if I got something wrong here, I'm happy to of course reopen and come back to it as needed

issue.title: RFC (Vue): Support usage in vue based web components with defineCustomElement

labels.name: future 🔮
labels.description: An enhancement or feature proposal that will be addressed after the next release

issue.body:
<!--
  🚨 RFCs are for proposed changes (not bugs or questions)
  Specifically they are whenever you'd like to see new features
  being added to urql, or enable new use-cases.
  They're also relevant whenever @urql/core is changed, since
  changes to e.g. the `Client` or `Exchange` types are kept rare
  and lean.
-->

## Summary
We have a micro app architecture relying on web components build with Vue's [defineCustomElements](https://vuejs.org/guide/extras/web-components.html#building-custom-elements-with-vue) function.
Therefor we have no app instance an no way to add urql as a plugin or use provide/inject.

A workaround would be of course not to use defineCustomelement and create the web components manually with an app instance, but we want to use defineCustomElement and reduce the manual work per web component (we will have probably 100+ web components in our mono repo).

## Proposed Solution

To enable this use case there are 2 possible changes that can achieve this:

**1. Add an optional client parameter to useClientHandle**
We could then use this parameter instead of useClient to get the client:
```ts
export function useClientHandle(clientArg?: Client): ClientHandle {
  const client = clientArg ?? useClient();
  //[...]
}
```

**2. Export all callUse\* functions**
If callUseQuery, callUseMutation, etc. functions are exported, we could build our own useClientHandle function based on those functions.

Solution 1 is the best solution if this should be an officially supported use case by `@urql/vue`. If not then solution 2 would allow a manual reuse of the vue functions for building a custom workaround. Both changes can also be implemented together of course.

If one (or both) of the proposed changes are welcome, I can provide a PR.

comment.body:
So, if I'm reading this correctly it does say,

> The Provide / Inject API and its Composition API equivalent also work between Vue-defined custom elements.

This is basically our mechanism to enforce that the Provide API is used to deliver a client to these APIs in a targeted manner. Bypassing this is of course possible — although, I will rule out option two here for you, sorry, it's simply not something we're keen on doing (a library, in our view, is not a set of tools to recompose said library, to us; this would diverge different usecases and happy paths too far between users)

Option 1 — providing a client ref or a client directly is of course possible. But, I want to make sure that this is necessary.

I haven't tested this myself yet, but could you validate for me please whether using `provideClient` in the same or a wrapping custom element that uses the query APIs really doesn't work? I think the docs imply it should 🤔 https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/9abce5d7b1f125d9edd666994e15ca8ae0dec7a6/packages/vue-urql/src/useClient.ts#L4

This PR was opened by the [Changesets release](https://github.com/changesets/action) GitHub action. When you're ready to do a release, you can merge this and the packages will be published to npm automatically. If you're not ready to do a release yet, that's fine, whenever you add more changesets to main, this PR will be updated.

# Releases
## @urql/exchange-graphcache@5.0.8

### Patch Changes

-   ⚠️ Fix operation being blocked for looping due to it not cancelling the looping protection when a `teardown` is received. This bug could be triggered when a shared query operation triggers again and causes a cache miss (e.g. due to an error). The re-execution of the operation would then be blocked as Graphcache considered it a "reexecution loop" rather than a legitimate execution triggered by the UI. (See <https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2737> for more information), by [@kitten](https://github.com/kitten) (See [#2876](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2876))

issue.title: Urql doesn't make a http request to the server on component remount and gets stuck on fetching.
issue.body:
### Describe the bug

I'm making a request to graphql server for an object using it's id. But the id is incorrect and no such object exists. So, the resolver checks the id and database for the object and if it doesn't exists throws a GraphqlError. Urql client receives this error in the graphQLErrors list on error object returned from the query. I'm checking the error object and rendering error message to the screen.

The first time this page is rendered everything works fine and the error message is rendered. But if I navigate away from the page and come back to it since the component unmounts and remounts urql client again makes the fetch request to the server because error results are not cached by urql I presume. 

The problem is that the refetch happens but urql client never sends a request to the server. I'm saying this because the fetching state returned from urql client turns to true. So, basically it gets stuck. Please look into this issue.

The codesandbox link I've attached shows two pages. User with id = 1 renders the data response. User with id != 1 renders the error response. Navigate away from the page and go back to it again. You can see the fetching state is stuck on fetching = true. In the network tab there's no request made to the server.

### Reproduction

https://codesandbox.io/p/github/xoldyckk/urql_nextjs_error/draft/tender-keldysh

### Urql version

urql v3.0.3
next-urql v4.0.0

### Validations

- [X] I can confirm that this is a bug report, and not a feature request, RFC, question, or discussion, for which [GitHub Discussions](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/discussions) should be used
- [X] Read the [docs](https://formidable.com/open-source/urql/docs/).

pull_request.title: fix(graphcache): Fix blocking of legitimate reexecutions after teardowns
pull_request.body:
Resolve #2835

## Summary

This fixes Graphcache blocking legitimate reexecutions triggerd by the UI. These reexecutions could be triggered due to the previously introduced looping protection #2737.

When an operation is torn down and reactivated without any other network request inbetween, then Graphcache wouldn't clean up the operations that'd be blocked from refetching. This meant that it'd erroneously block a legitimate operation triggered by the UI.

The protection is meant to only trigger requests that'd potentially infinitely trigger requests, i.e. non-`network-only` operations triggered by cache misses.

This has been addressed by adding a missing clean up call in reaction to teardowns.

## Set of changes

- Add missing `reexecutingOperations` clean up to `teardown` handler
- Remove typings/build testing line that we added to test a Rollup+TS build issue

comment.body:
I've taken a look and can confirm that this is an issue with the loop protection. We did recently fix another issue with it here, for reference: https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2831

The original implementation is here: https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/pull/2737

What we basically likely didn't account for are cases where the same query triggers again across multiple pages, i.e. explicit operations being triggered by the consuming client.

We'd likely have to find a way to better differentiate between `reexecuteOperation` loops and actual triggers in Graphcache, I'd suspect we'll need to take `teardown`s into account to check for this.

I'll see whether I can start a fix soon, and I'll link it to here once we do :v:

pull_request.title: fix(core): Fix regression causing stringifyDocument to not reprint after formatDocument
pull_request.body:
## Summary

Related to #2869 reproduces the issue.

[this](https://github.com/urql-graphql/urql/blob/main/packages/core/src/utils/request.ts#L43-L53) looks to be the problem, when we use `createRequest` we fill in `gql` as the source name and don't update the printed string when looping over it with `formatDocument`. When we use `gql` the name will be `graphql request` hence not hitting this clause.

The thing concerning me here is if people would be implementing local-only exchanges whether that would mess with i.e. them removing a field when seeing `@local`
